sn48.23:1.3.eng: The faculty of understanding that one’s enlightenment is imminent. The faculty of enlightenment. The faculty of one who is enlightened.

sn48.24:1.3.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.24:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ samattā paripūrattā arahaṃ hoti, tato mudutarehi antarāparinibbāyī hoti, tato mudutarehi upahaccaparinibbāyī hoti, tato mudutarehi asaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti, tato mudutarehi sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti, tato mudutarehi uddhaṃsoto hoti akaniṭṭhagāmī, tato mudutarehi sakadāgāmī hoti, tato mudutarehi ekabījī hoti, tato mudutarehi kolaṅkolo hoti, tato mudutarehi sattakkhattuparamo hoti, tato mudutarehi dhammānusārī hoti, tato mudutarehi saddhānusārī hotī”ti.
sn48.24:1.5.eng: Someone who has completed and fulfilled these five faculties is a perfected one. If they are weaker than that, they’re one who is extinguished between one life and the next … one who is extinguished upon landing … one who is extinguished without extra effort … one who is extinguished with extra effort … one who heads upstream, going to the Akaniṭṭha realm … a once-returner … a one-seeder … one who goes from family to family … one who has seven rebirths at most … a follower of teachings … a follower by faith.”

sn48.25:1.3.pli: Cakkhundriyaṃ, sotindriyaṃ, ghānindriyaṃ, jivhindriyaṃ, kāyindriyaṃ, manindriyaṃ—
sn48.25:1.3.eng: The faculties of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

sn48.26:1.3.eng: The faculties of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

sn48.26:1.4.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako imesaṃ channaṃ indriyānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti—
sn48.26:1.4.eng: A noble disciple comes to truly understand these six faculties’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape.

sn48.26:1.5.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako sotāpanno avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo”ti.
sn48.26:1.5.eng: Such a noble disciple is called a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn48.27:1.3.pli: Cakkhundriyaṃ, sotindriyaṃ, ghānindriyaṃ, jivhindriyaṃ, kāyindriyaṃ, manindriyaṃ.
sn48.27:1.3.eng: The faculties of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

sn48.27:1.4.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imesaṃ channaṃ indriyānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā anupādāvimutto hoti—
sn48.27:1.4.eng: A mendicant comes to be freed by not grasping after truly understanding these six faculties’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape.

sn48.27:1.5.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘bhikkhu arahaṃ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammadaññāvimutto’”ti.
sn48.27:1.5.eng: Such a mendicant is called a perfected one, with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment.”

sn48.28:1.3.pli: Cakkhundriyaṃ, sotindriyaṃ, ghānindriyaṃ, jivhindriyaṃ, kāyindriyaṃ, manindriyaṃ.
sn48.28:1.3.eng: The faculties of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

sn48.28:1.4.pli: Yāvakīvañcāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ channaṃ indriyānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nābbhaññāsiṃ, neva tāvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya ‘anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho’ti paccaññāsiṃ.
sn48.28:1.4.eng: As long as I didn’t truly understand these six faculties’ gratification, drawback, and escape, I didn’t announce my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

sn48.28:1.5.pli: Yato ca khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ channaṃ indriyānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, athāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya ‘anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho’ti paccaññāsiṃ.
sn48.28:1.5.eng: But when I did truly understand these six faculties’ gratification, drawback, and escape, I announced my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

sn48.28:1.6.eng: Knowledge and vision arose in me:

sn48.28:1.7.pli: ‘akuppā me vimutti, ayamantimā jāti, natthi dāni punabbhavo’”ti.
sn48.28:1.7.eng: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’”

sn48.29:1.3.pli: Cakkhundriyaṃ, sotindriyaṃ, ghānindriyaṃ, jivhindriyaṃ, kāyindriyaṃ, manindriyaṃ.
sn48.29:1.3.eng: The faculties of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

sn48.29:1.4.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā imesaṃ channaṃ indriyānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti,
sn48.29:1.4.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape when it comes to these six faculties.

sn48.29:1.5.pli: na me te, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu vā samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu vā brāhmaṇasammatā, na ca panete āyasmanto sāmaññatthaṃ vā brahmaññatthaṃ vā diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti.
sn48.29:1.5.eng: I don’t deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables don’t realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and don’t live having realized it with their own insight.

sn48.29:1.6.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā imesaṃ channaṃ indriyānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti,
sn48.29:1.6.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape when it comes to these six faculties.

sn48.29:1.7.pli: te kho me, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu ceva samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu ca brāhmaṇasammatā, te ca panāyasmanto sāmaññatthañca brahmaññatthañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī”ti.
sn48.29:1.7.eng: I deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and live having realized it with their own insight.”

sn48.3:1.3.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.3:1.4.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako imesaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti—
sn48.3:1.4.eng: A noble disciple comes to truly understand these five faculties’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape.

sn48.3:1.5.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako sotāpanno avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo”ti.
sn48.3:1.5.eng: Such a noble disciple is called a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn48.30:1.1.pli: “Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā cakkhundriyaṃ nappajānanti, cakkhundriyasamudayaṃ nappajānanti, cakkhundriyanirodhaṃ nappajānanti, cakkhundriyanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ nappajānanti;
sn48.30:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t understand the eye faculty, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn48.30:1.2.eng: They don’t understand the ear faculty …

sn48.30:1.6.pli: manindriyaṃ nappajānanti, manindriyasamudayaṃ nappajānanti, manindriyanirodhaṃ nappajānanti, manindriyanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ nappajānanti.
sn48.30:1.6.eng: mind faculty, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn48.30:1.7.pli: Na me te, bhikkhave …pe… sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti.
sn48.30:1.7.eng: I don’t deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables don’t realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and don’t live having realized it with their own insight.

sn48.30:2.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā cakkhundriyaṃ pajānanti, cakkhundriyasamudayaṃ pajānanti, cakkhundriyanirodhaṃ pajānanti, cakkhundriyanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānanti,
sn48.30:2.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do understand the eye faculty, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn48.30:2.6.pli: manindriyaṃ pajānanti, manindriyasamudayaṃ pajānanti, manindriyanirodhaṃ pajānanti, manindriyanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānanti,
sn48.30:2.6.eng: mind faculty, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn48.30:2.7.pli: te kho me, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu ceva samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu ca brāhmaṇasammatā, te ca panāyasmanto sāmaññatthañca brahmaññatthañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī”ti.
sn48.30:2.7.eng: I deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and live having realized it with their own insight.”

sn48.31:1.3.eng: The faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity.

sn48.32:1.3.eng: The faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity.

sn48.32:1.4.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako imesaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti—
sn48.32:1.4.eng: A noble disciple comes to truly understand these five faculties’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape.

sn48.32:1.5.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako sotāpanno avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo”ti.
sn48.32:1.5.eng: Such a noble disciple is called a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn48.33:1.3.eng: The faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity.

sn48.33:1.4.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imesaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā anupādāvimutto hoti—
sn48.33:1.4.eng: A mendicant comes to be freed by not grasping after truly understanding these five faculties’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape.

sn48.33:1.5.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu arahaṃ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammadaññāvimutto”ti.
sn48.33:1.5.eng: Such a mendicant is called a perfected one, with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment.”

sn48.34:1.3.eng: The faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity.

sn48.34:1.4.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā imesaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti,
sn48.34:1.4.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape when it comes to these five faculties.

sn48.34:1.5.pli: na me te, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu vā samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu vā brāhmaṇasammatā, na ca panete āyasmanto sāmaññatthaṃ vā brahmaññatthaṃ vā diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti.
sn48.34:1.5.eng: I don’t deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables don’t realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and don’t live having realized it with their own insight.

sn48.34:2.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā imesaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti,
sn48.34:2.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape when it comes to these five faculties.

sn48.34:2.2.pli: te kho me, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu ceva samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu ca brāhmaṇasammatā, te ca panāyasmanto sāmaññatthañca brahmaññatthañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī”ti.
sn48.34:2.2.eng: I deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and live having realized it with their own insight.”

sn48.35:1.3.eng: The faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity.

sn48.35:1.4.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā sukhindriyaṃ nappajānanti, sukhindriyasamudayaṃ nappajānanti, sukhindriyanirodhaṃ nappajānanti, sukhindriyanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ nappajānanti;
sn48.35:1.4.eng: Mendicants, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t understand the faculty of pleasure, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn48.35:1.5.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t understand the faculty of pain …

sn48.35:1.8.pli: upekkhindriyaṃ nappajānanti, upekkhindriyasamudayaṃ nappajānanti, upekkhindriyanirodhaṃ nappajānanti, upekkhindriyanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ nappajānanti;
sn48.35:1.8.eng: equanimity, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn48.35:1.9.pli: na me te, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu vā samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu vā brāhmaṇasammatā, na ca panete āyasmanto sāmaññatthaṃ vā brahmaññatthaṃ vā diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti.
sn48.35:1.9.eng: I don’t deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables don’t realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and don’t live having realized it with their own insight.

sn48.35:2.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā sukhindriyaṃ pajānanti, sukhindriyasamudayaṃ pajānanti, sukhindriyanirodhaṃ pajānanti, sukhindriyanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānanti;
sn48.35:2.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do understand the faculty of pleasure, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn48.35:2.2.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do understand the faculty of pain …

sn48.35:2.5.pli: upekkhindriyaṃ pajānanti, upekkhindriyasamudayaṃ pajānanti, upekkhindriyanirodhaṃ pajānanti, upekkhindriyanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānanti,
sn48.35:2.5.eng: equanimity, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn48.35:2.6.pli: te ca kho me, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu ceva samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu ca brāhmaṇasammatā, te ca panāyasmanto sāmaññatthañca brahmaññatthañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī”ti.
sn48.35:2.6.eng: I deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and live having realized it with their own insight.”

sn48.36:1.3.eng: The faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity.

sn48.36:2.1.eng: And what is the faculty of pleasure?

sn48.36:2.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, kāyikaṃ sukhaṃ, kāyikaṃ sātaṃ, kāyasamphassajaṃ sukhaṃ sātaṃ vedayitaṃ—
sn48.36:2.2.eng: Physical enjoyment, physical pleasure, the enjoyable, pleasant feeling that’s born from physical contact.

sn48.36:2.3.eng: This is called the faculty of pleasure.

sn48.36:3.1.eng: And what is the faculty of pain?

sn48.36:3.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, kāyikaṃ dukkhaṃ, kāyikaṃ asātaṃ, kāyasamphassajaṃ dukkhaṃ asātaṃ vedayitaṃ—
sn48.36:3.2.eng: Physical pain, physical unpleasantness, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from physical contact.

sn48.36:3.3.eng: This is called the faculty of pain.

sn48.36:4.1.eng: And what is the faculty of happiness?

sn48.36:4.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, cetasikaṃ sukhaṃ, cetasikaṃ sātaṃ, manosamphassajaṃ sukhaṃ sātaṃ vedayitaṃ—
sn48.36:4.2.eng: Mental enjoyment, mental pleasure, the enjoyable, pleasant feeling that’s born from mind contact.

sn48.36:4.3.eng: This is called the faculty of happiness.

sn48.36:5.1.eng: And what is the faculty of sadness?

sn48.36:5.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, cetasikaṃ dukkhaṃ, cetasikaṃ asātaṃ, manosamphassajaṃ dukkhaṃ asātaṃ vedayitaṃ—
sn48.36:5.2.eng: Mental pain, mental displeasure, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from mind contact.

sn48.36:5.3.eng: This is called the faculty of sadness.

sn48.36:6.1.eng: And what is the faculty of equanimity?

sn48.36:6.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, kāyikaṃ vā cetasikaṃ vā nevasātaṃ nāsātaṃ vedayitaṃ—
sn48.36:6.2.eng: Neither pleasant nor unpleasant feeling, whether physical or mental.

sn48.36:6.3.eng: This is the faculty of equanimity.

sn48.37:1.3.eng: The faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity.

sn48.37:2.1.eng: And what is the faculty of pleasure?

sn48.37:2.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, kāyikaṃ sukhaṃ, kāyikaṃ sātaṃ, kāyasamphassajaṃ sukhaṃ sātaṃ vedayitaṃ—
sn48.37:2.2.eng: Physical enjoyment, physical pleasure, the enjoyable, pleasant feeling that’s born from physical contact.

sn48.37:2.3.eng: This is called the faculty of pleasure.

sn48.37:3.1.eng: And what is the faculty of pain?

sn48.37:3.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, kāyikaṃ dukkhaṃ, kāyikaṃ asātaṃ, kāyasamphassajaṃ dukkhaṃ asātaṃ vedayitaṃ—
sn48.37:3.2.eng: Physical pain, physical unpleasantness, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from physical contact.

sn48.37:3.3.eng: This is called the faculty of pain.

sn48.37:4.1.eng: And what is the faculty of happiness?

sn48.37:4.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, cetasikaṃ sukhaṃ, cetasikaṃ sātaṃ, manosamphassajaṃ sukhaṃ sātaṃ vedayitaṃ—
sn48.37:4.2.eng: Mental enjoyment, mental pleasure, the enjoyable, pleasant feeling that’s born from mind contact.

sn48.37:4.3.eng: This is called the faculty of happiness.

sn48.37:5.1.eng: And what is the faculty of sadness?

sn48.37:5.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, cetasikaṃ dukkhaṃ, cetasikaṃ asātaṃ, manosamphassajaṃ dukkhaṃ asātaṃ vedayitaṃ—
sn48.37:5.2.eng: Mental pain, mental displeasure, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from mind contact.

sn48.37:5.3.eng: This is called the faculty of sadness.

sn48.37:6.1.eng: And what is the faculty of equanimity?

sn48.37:6.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, kāyikaṃ vā cetasikaṃ vā nevasātaṃ nāsātaṃ vedayitaṃ—
sn48.37:6.2.eng: Neither pleasant nor unpleasant feeling, whether physical or mental.

sn48.37:6.3.eng: This is the faculty of equanimity.

sn48.37:7.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yañca sukhindriyaṃ yañca somanassindriyaṃ, sukhā sā vedanā daṭṭhabbā.
sn48.37:7.1.eng: In this context, the faculties of pleasure and happiness should be seen as pleasant feeling.

sn48.37:7.2.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yañca dukkhindriyaṃ yañca domanassindriyaṃ, dukkhā sā vedanā daṭṭhabbā.
sn48.37:7.2.eng: The faculties of pain and sadness should be seen as painful feeling.

sn48.37:7.3.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yadidaṃ upekkhindriyaṃ, adukkhamasukhā sā vedanā daṭṭhabbā.
sn48.37:7.3.eng: The faculty of equanimity should be seen as neutral feeling.

sn48.38:1.3.eng: The faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity.

sn48.38:2.1.eng: And what is the faculty of pleasure?

sn48.38:2.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, kāyikaṃ sukhaṃ, kāyikaṃ sātaṃ, kāyasamphassajaṃ sukhaṃ sātaṃ vedayitaṃ—
sn48.38:2.2.eng: Physical enjoyment, physical pleasure, the enjoyable, pleasant feeling that’s born from physical contact.

sn48.38:2.3.eng: This is called the faculty of pleasure.

sn48.38:3.1.eng: And what is the faculty of pain?

sn48.38:3.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, kāyikaṃ dukkhaṃ, kāyikaṃ asātaṃ, kāyasamphassajaṃ dukkhaṃ asātaṃ vedayitaṃ—
sn48.38:3.2.eng: Physical pain, physical unpleasantness, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from physical contact.

sn48.38:3.3.eng: This is called the faculty of pain.

sn48.38:4.1.eng: And what is the faculty of happiness?

sn48.38:4.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, cetasikaṃ sukhaṃ, cetasikaṃ sātaṃ, manosamphassajaṃ sukhaṃ sātaṃ vedayitaṃ—
sn48.38:4.2.eng: Mental enjoyment, mental pleasure, the enjoyable, pleasant feeling that’s born from mind contact.

sn48.38:4.3.eng: This is called the faculty of happiness.

sn48.38:5.1.eng: And what is the faculty of sadness?

sn48.38:5.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, cetasikaṃ dukkhaṃ, cetasikaṃ asātaṃ, manosamphassajaṃ dukkhaṃ asātaṃ vedayitaṃ—
sn48.38:5.2.eng: Mental pain, mental displeasure, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from mind contact.

sn48.38:5.3.eng: This is called the faculty of sadness.

sn48.38:6.1.eng: And what is the faculty of equanimity?

sn48.38:6.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, kāyikaṃ vā cetasikaṃ vā neva sātaṃ nāsātaṃ vedayitaṃ—
sn48.38:6.2.eng: Neither pleasant nor unpleasant feeling, whether physical or mental.

sn48.38:6.3.eng: This is the faculty of equanimity.

sn48.38:7.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yañca sukhindriyaṃ yañca somanassindriyaṃ, sukhā sā vedanā daṭṭhabbā.
sn48.38:7.1.eng: In this context, the faculties of pleasure and happiness should be seen as pleasant feeling.

sn48.38:7.2.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yañca dukkhindriyaṃ yañca domanassindriyaṃ, dukkhā sā vedanā daṭṭhabbā.
sn48.38:7.2.eng: The faculties of pain and sadness should be seen as painful feeling.

sn48.38:7.3.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yadidaṃ upekkhindriyaṃ, adukkhamasukhā sā vedanā daṭṭhabbā.
sn48.38:7.3.eng: The faculty of equanimity should be seen as neutral feeling.

sn48.38:7.4.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, imāni pañcindriyāni pañca hutvā tīṇi honti, tīṇi hutvā pañca honti pariyāyenā”ti.
sn48.38:7.4.eng: That’s how these five faculties, depending on how they’re explained, having been five become three, and having been three become five.”

sn48.39:0.3.eng: The Simile of the Fire Sticks

sn48.39:1.3.eng: The faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity.

sn48.39:1.4.pli: Sukhavedaniyaṃ, bhikkhave, phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhindriyaṃ.
sn48.39:1.4.eng: The faculty of pleasure arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant.

sn48.39:1.5.eng: When in a state of pleasure, you understand: ‘I’m in a state of pleasure.’

sn48.39:1.6.pli: Tasseva sukhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā ‘yaṃ tajjaṃ vedayitaṃ sukhavedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppannaṃ sukhindriyaṃ taṃ nirujjhati, taṃ vūpasammatī’ti pajānāti.
sn48.39:1.6.eng: With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as pleasant, you understand that the corresponding faculty of pleasure ceases and stops.

sn48.39:2.1.pli: Dukkhavedaniyaṃ, bhikkhave, phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dukkhindriyaṃ.
sn48.39:2.1.eng: The faculty of pain arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as painful.

sn48.39:2.2.eng: When in a state of pain, you understand: ‘I’m in a state of pain.’

sn48.39:2.3.pli: Tasseva dukkhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā ‘yaṃ tajjaṃ vedayitaṃ dukkhavedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppannaṃ dukkhindriyaṃ taṃ nirujjhati, taṃ vūpasammatī’ti pajānāti.
sn48.39:2.3.eng: With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as painful, you understand that the corresponding faculty of pain ceases and stops.

sn48.39:3.1.pli: Somanassavedaniyaṃ, bhikkhave, phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati somanassindriyaṃ.
sn48.39:3.1.eng: The faculty of happiness arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as happiness.

sn48.39:3.2.eng: When in a state of happiness, you understand: ‘I’m in a state of happiness.’

sn48.39:3.3.pli: Tasseva somanassavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā ‘yaṃ tajjaṃ vedayitaṃ somanassavedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppannaṃ somanassindriyaṃ taṃ nirujjhati, taṃ vūpasammatī’ti pajānāti.
sn48.39:3.3.eng: With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as happiness, you understand that the corresponding faculty of happiness ceases and stops.

sn48.39:4.1.pli: Domanassavedaniyaṃ, bhikkhave, phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati domanassindriyaṃ.
sn48.39:4.1.eng: The faculty of sadness arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as sadness.

sn48.39:4.2.eng: When in a state of sadness, you understand: ‘I’m in a state of sadness.’

sn48.39:4.3.pli: Tasseva domanassavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā ‘yaṃ tajjaṃ vedayitaṃ domanassavedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppannaṃ domanassindriyaṃ taṃ nirujjhati, taṃ vūpasammatī’ti pajānāti.
sn48.39:4.3.eng: With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as sadness, you understand that the corresponding faculty of sadness ceases and stops.

sn48.39:5.1.pli: Upekkhāvedaniyaṃ, bhikkhave, phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati upekkhindriyaṃ.
sn48.39:5.1.eng: The faculty of equanimity arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as equanimous.

sn48.39:5.2.eng: When in a state of equanimity, you understand: ‘I’m in a state of equanimity.’

sn48.39:5.3.pli: Tasseva upekkhāvedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā ‘yaṃ tajjaṃ vedayitaṃ upekkhāvedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppannaṃ upekkhindriyaṃ taṃ nirujjhati, taṃ vūpasammatī’ti pajānāti.
sn48.39:5.3.eng: With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as equanimous, you understand that the corresponding faculty of equanimity ceases and stops.

sn48.39:6.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dvinnaṃ kaṭṭhānaṃ saṅghaṭṭanasamodhānā usmā jāyati, tejo abhinibbattati; tesaṃyeva kaṭṭhānaṃ nānābhāvāvinikkhepā yā tajjā usmā sā nirujjhati sā vūpasammati;
sn48.39:6.1.eng: When you rub two sticks together, heat is generated and fire is produced. But when you part the sticks and lay them aside, any corresponding heat ceases and stops.

sn48.39:6.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, sukhavedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhindriyaṃ.
sn48.39:6.2.eng: In the same way, the faculty of pleasure arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant.

sn48.39:6.3.eng: When in a state of pleasure, you understand: ‘I’m in a state of pleasure.’

sn48.39:6.4.pli: Tasseva sukhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā ‘yaṃ tajjaṃ vedayitaṃ sukhavedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhindriyaṃ taṃ nirujjhati, taṃ vūpasammatī’ti pajānāti.
sn48.39:6.4.eng: With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as pleasant, you understand that the corresponding faculty of pleasure ceases and stops.

sn48.39:7.4.pli: upekkhāvedaniyaṃ, bhikkhave, phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati upekkhindriyaṃ.
sn48.39:7.4.eng: equanimity arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as equanimous.

sn48.39:7.5.eng: When in a state of equanimity, you understand: ‘I’m in a state of equanimity.’

sn48.39:7.6.pli: Tasseva upekkhāvedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā ‘yaṃ tajjaṃ vedayitaṃ upekkhāvedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati upekkhindriyaṃ taṃ nirujjhati, taṃ vūpasammatī’ti pajānāti”.
sn48.39:7.6.eng: With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as equanimous, you understand that the corresponding faculty of equanimity ceases and stops.”
